awd_titl_txt: Advanced organic and hybrid electronic devices for high-resolution Hall effect and photocurrent spectroscopy.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical:
This research project focuses on the working principles of transistors and photo-detectors based on two classes of novel materials. Organic semiconductors and organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites are promising materials for applications in solar cells, flexible electronics, sensors and actuators. High-purity single crystals of these materials are expected to conduct charge efficiently, have long charge carrier lifetimes, and tolerate defects. All of these properties are attractive for future applications in optoelectronics. The research team will characterize electrical conduction with high-precision of organic and perovskite devices under various external stimuli. Stimuli include calibrated mechanical strain, performed by bending flexible devices, illumination with visible light and varied temperature. These studies will yield a better understanding of the unique properties of these novel materials and behavior of devices based on them. The project will boost the development of flexible transistors and photo-detectors and yield powerful methods to characterize these devices. This project will give students an opportunity to perform research on emerging electronic materials. Aspiring researchers will learn semiconductor science, acquire modern research skills and prepare for careers in science and technology.

Technical:
Novel electronic devices based on emergent highly crystalline organic semiconductors and perovskite materials are under intense research for their potential use in the next-generation optoelectronic applications. The main focus of this project is to significantly advance the fundamental understanding of operating principles and microscopic mechanisms governing the behavior of organic field-effect transistors and perovskite photo-conductors. The research team plans to achieve this by employing a unique and powerful combination of high-resolution ac-Hall effect measurements, an in-situ application of calibrated uniaxial mechanical strains, variable temperature and/or photoexcitation, as well as using complementary theoretical modeling in order to understand the intrinsic (trap-free) charge carrier mobilities, electron-hole recombination rates, carrier lifetimes and diffusion lengths in these devices. Implementation of the project is expected to result in the development of high-performance, flexible organic field-effect transistors based ultra-thin organic crystals and optimized perovskite photo-conductors with chemically passivated surfaces, lead to new methodologies of high-precision Hall effect measurements, especially important for emergent ?soft? and flexible electronics, and more broadly contribute to a better understanding of the electronic, photonic and magneto-transport properties of novel semiconductor devices. The interdisciplinary nature of this project provides excellent educational, human resource and outreach opportunities in the area of optoelectronics and semiconductor device engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this NSF project were: (A) the development of high-performance transistors based on high-purity, single crystalline perovskites (the novel materials of interest for solar-cell and other optoelectronic applications) and organic semiconductors (materials composed of van der Waals bonded conjugated hydrocarbon molecules); and (B) investigating properties of these electronic devices related to their ability to conduct electricity by taking advantage of the high-resolution Hall effect methodology developed at Rutgers University.  

The two major accomplishments of this project are outlined below. First, we have successfully developed the first intrinsic (that is, not dominated by defects), high-performance perovskite transistors, as described in V. Bruevich et al., The Intrinsic (Trap-Free) Transistors Based on Epitaxial Single-Crystal Perovskites, Adv. Mater. https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202205055 (2022). This study is a seminal contribution to the perovskite research, because it describes the growth of perovskites and device fabrication leading to the perovskite transistors of significantly higher quality than analogous devices demonstrated in this field earlier. More importantly, this work reveals, for the first time, the intrinsic (not dominated by disorder) charge transport properties of the investigated perovskite that can now be used as a feedback to theory and other experimental efforts. The novel epitaxial CVD growth technique used in this project leads to macroscopically large-area, nearly defect-free, single crystalline perovskite films that can now be adopted for other perovskites. Fabrication of truly high-performance perovskite transistors with record-high charge carrier mobilities and other beneficial device characteristics is thus a breakthrough in perovskite research.

Second, we have demonstrated and investigated a photo-Hall effect in organic semiconductors, which has been done in these materials for the first time (V. Bruevich, H. H. Choi, V. Podzorov, The Photo-Hall Effect in High-Mobility Organic Semiconductors, Adv. Funct. Mater. https://doi.org/10.1002/adfm.202006178 (2020)). Using an ultra-pure, highly crystalline organic semiconductor rubrene, we have carried out high-sensitivity Hall-effect measurements that have directly revealed the intrinsic (not dominated by defects) charge carrier mobility at the surface and in the bulk of this organic semiconductor. Our data uncovered new details of the physical mechanism of photocarrier generation and transport in this class of materials, highlighting the importance of long-lived, mobile excitons and their interaction with crystal's surfaces.

The main results of this project will have a strong and lasting impact on the fields of perovskite and organic electronics and, more broadly, on the semiconductor physics and material science. Unlike the majority of previously reported perovskite transistors, this project has opened an avenue to truly high-performance perovskite transistors with physical properties not limited by static disorder (grain boundaries, crystal defects, and electronic traps). Our work thus shows that epitaxial perovskites emerge as a perfect platform for the fundamental studies of charge transport phenomena in this important class of materials, paving a way for a plethora of better perovskite-based devices, potentially including more efficient light emitting devices, electrically pumped injection lasers, radiation detectors, sensors and memories.

This project has also led to the development of several new custom-made experimental techniques at Rutgers University, including the photo-Hall effect measurements, a novel CVD furnace for the epitaxial growth of complex materials, and a temperature-variable capability for the high-resolution Hall effect measurements. Beyond its own discipline, this project has also made a broader impact by contributing to several other relevant fields, including the development of novel epitaxial growth of thin films, surface science of complex compounds, and ion-beam microscopies.

This project has provided excellent opportunities for experimental training and professional development for several young researchers involved in this work who collaborated on the characterization of epitaxial perovskite films and organic crystals using a range of analytical material characterization techniques, including x-ray and ion scattering spectroscopies, photoemission spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy, and high-precision electrical measurements.

The results of this project were disseminated via contributed and invited talks at several major international conferences, including ACS-2021, Spring MRS-2021, and SPIE-2022, as well as through publications in high-impact peer-reviewed journals (in total, 7 papers have been published).  For details on these and other results, please visit the group's webpage at Rutgers University:  http://www.physics.rutgers.edu/~podzorov/index.php
